childNodes.textContent: AWS provides a similar containerized PostHog environment to
. Through the use of AWS Fargate, we are able to provide a
platform to prevent you from overpaying!
to deploy PostHog with Redis and Postgres on an AWS stack.
If you're new to CloudFormations and want to learn more and how to use them, check out these
After clicking "Next" you'll have the option to review the parameters. You will need to update these if you want to modify default behaviors, get alarms, or setup SMTP configs as described below.
Review the rest of the Configuration Wizard pages
(Optional) On the 'Review Stack' page you can click
to get an estimate of how much your specific config will cost per month. The default configs cost about ~$27 USD per month
Review all parameters in the config and ensure everything is nominal.
If you filled out Alarm email, then check your email to confirm SNS subscription.
Add a listener for the protocol HTTPS, import or add your SSL certificate
After verifying it works, you can disable insecure access by removing the listener for port 80 (HTTP).
Do this to get the latest and greatest version of posthog. Follow these steps:
Open up your AWS console to
Make sure you have your Region set to the correct region.
page, select the name of the cluster running PostHog
On the cluster page select the services tab
Check the box on the left of the PostHog service and click the
page, PostHog's service information is already pre-populated. You
to instruct ECS to pull a new container from the Docker repository. From there make any relevant changes to the configuration if you want to. If all that is needed is an update proceed to
to 🚢 the newest version of PostHog to your ECS cluster!
You can find more details on Amazon's Docs for
Do this to update parameters: to scale different services up/down, update who gets alarms, STMP or more.
Go to the CloudFormation page on your AWS
Find your stack, select it, click update
Select replace current template and use this url:
Review parameters and other pages and update stack.
PostHog can be found on the AWS Marketplace. To deploy it, you just need to access the page and follow the steps to configure your instance.
Here's a short step by step tutorial:
Ensure you're logged in to AWS
PostHog page on the AWS Marketplace
You will be prompted with a page to review your subscription. The subscription to PostHog via AWS Marketplace is
, so the only thing you'll need to pay for are the AWS Resources you use with your PostHog instance.
Once your subscription is ready, you should receive an email about it. You can then view all your subscriptions on the
From the 'Your Software' page, you should now see PostHog. Click 'Launch Instance' on it.

This will prompt you with the configuration steps before you launch. You should fill this according to your preferences. Regarding the Instance Type, we recommend a config with about the following specs for a medium volume instance:

However, this will vary based on the volume you're expecting. If you're expecting a low volume, a lighter instance may do just fine. AWS suggests EC2 by default, which has a free tier available. This might be suitable for users not expecting to do heavy l
Finish the configuration steps according to your personal preferences. Setting up security groups is probably a good idea.
Launch the instance and you're all set!

If instead of using our CloudFormation config or AWS Marketplace app you would rather go through the deployment yourself, here's how to do it. We'll be using Docker for this tutorial but you could also
Ensure you're logged in to AWS
Select your AMI. For this tutorial, we'll be using the
You will be prompted with a page to choose your instance type. We recommend a config with about the following specs for a medium volume instance:

However, this will vary based on the volume you're expecting. If you're expecting a low volume, a lighter instance may do just fine. EC2 has a free tier available and this might be suitable for users not expecting to do heavy load analytics yet, as well a
Once your instance is live, you should get a notification. That means you're ready to move on to the next tutorial.
SSH into your EC2 instance by using the IP provided on your console instead of
. On a terminal, this should look something like this:
If you downloaded a new key during the creation of the Virtual Machine, you may need to run:
Setup Docker to run without root priviledges
To clone the PostHog repository and enter the new directory, run:
You'll then need to generate a
that is unique to your instance.
⚠️ Note: Do not use our placeholder key! Read more about the importance of this key
. This will generate a new key for you. You'll need this in the next step.
for the key you got from the key generation command.
line will end up looking something like this (with your key, of course):
You're good to go! PostHog should be accessible on the domain you set up or the IP of your instance.
If you do not have a TLS/SSL certificate set up for your domain/IP, accessing the address of your PostHog instance
. To get around this, you need to edit the
file manually and add the environment variables
. This is a manual process because PostHog should not be run without a certificate (i.e. over HTTP).
Doing this and restarting the service will allow you to access PostHog over HTTP, but might require configuring browser settings to allow HTTP traffic depending on what browser you use.

childNodes.textContent: Through Docker, PostHogers can install specific versions of the app while also having it within a containerized environment.
, so you have the latest features and security updates!
If you are deploying with Docker on AWS or Digital Ocean, you can check our individual specific tutorials instead of following this generic tutorial:
Setup Docker to run without root priviledges
To clone the PostHog repository and enter the new directory, run:
that is unique to your instance.
⚠️ Note: Do not use our placeholder key! Read more about the importance of this key
. This will generate a new key for you. You'll need this in the next step.
for the key you got from the key generation command.
line will end up looking something like this (with your key, of course):
You're good to go! PostHog should be accessible on the domain you set up or the IP of your instance.
If you do not have a TLS/SSL certificate set up for your domain/IP, accessing the address of your PostHog instance
. To get around this, you need to edit the
file manually and add the environment variables
. This is a manual process because PostHog should not be run without a certificate (i.e. over HTTP).
Doing this and restarting the service will allow you to access PostHog over HTTP, but might require configuring browser settings to allow HTTP traffic depending on what browser you use.
If you're running locally, use our
If you're running your Postgres database elsewhere (i.e. RDS, or a different server) you can edit the docker-compose file and do the following:
property to the location of your database
If you would like to run the software locally, you can use a Docker preview. Note that this is
Paste the following snippet into your terminal:
Upgrading PostHog with Docker depends on how you've deployed with Docker.
You may need to store your secret key and update the
how to setup your secret key with Docker Compose.
If you've pinned a version, see
PostHog is now using Redis with a worker to process events and other background tasks. If you're getting a
in the interface, you'll need to setup a Redis server and run the worker process.
If you're using a docker-compose file, either pull the latest version from
, or add the following to your docker-compose file:
If you last updated PostHog before 3 March 2020
you have a lot of events, there is one migration (0027) that might take a long time.
If you only have a few thousand events, you probably don't need to worry about this.
If you need help on any of the above, feel free to create an issue on
where a member of our team can assist you! Chances are that if you have a problem or question, someone else does too - so please don't hesitate to create a new issue or ask us a question.
